de.pbc.stata

Interface Plugin


  • public interface Plugin

    In order for DPL to load a plugin dynamically, the plugin has to implement this interface. execute(String[]) is the instantiated entry point: All work to be done in the plugin should start in execute(String[]).

    The execution environment in execute(String[]) is identical to Stata invoking a static entry point. That is, everything you can access via the SFI API (e.g., varlist, if, in) and the supplied arguments are identical.

    Consider the following example: 

     public class YourPlugin implements Plugin {
        // This is the static entry point as you may want to use it for productive scenarios
        // All it does is instantiate your plugin and call execute(...).
        private static int staticEntryPoint(String[] args) {
                return new YourPlugin().execute(args);
        }
 
        // This is where all the action happens.
         @Override
        public int execute(String[] args) throws Exception {
                // do your work here
                return 0;
        }
 }
    During development PluginLoader invokes execute(String[]) directly. For productive use, your module is invoked by Stata via staticEntryPoint(String[]). Once inside execute(String[]) the difference is indistinguishable.

    Version:
    2015-05-20
    Author:
    Philipp B. Cornelius

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      int execute(java.lang.String[] args)
      This is where the plugin should do its work.

    • Method Detail

      • execute

        int execute(java.lang.String[] args)
     throws java.lang.Exception
        This is where the plugin should do its work. Please refer to the Stata manual as to what APIs are available and what are acceptable return codes.
        Parameters:
        args - a String array of arguments supplied to your module by Stata
        Returns:
        see Stata's manual for acceptable return codes
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - any uncaught exception will lead to PluginLoader returning with 44 and printing the exception and its stack trace to the Stata console
